MajorClaims.MC1: exams have a role to play in ensuring proper and objective assessment of achievement

Claims.C1: exams need to be carefully designed and supplemented with other forms of evaluation if they are to be a truly useful component of the education system
Claims.C2: There are clearly advantages to exams
Claims.C4: A number of measures should be taken to address these concerns

Premises.P1: They help to ensure fairness by imposing the same conditions on all exam candidates
Premises.P2: They are also relatively versatile; different types of exam questions, for example, multiple-choice questions and essay tasks, can test different sorts of reasoning ability
Premises.P3: Test-wise candidates can often perform well on exams without having good underlying knowledge or skills
Premises.P4: some test-takers perform cannot achieve a satisfying result because of anxiety
Premises.P5: teachers and learners focus only on theses aspects of the curriculum that are likely to be tested, thus narrowing the educational experience for all
Premises.P6: exams should match the content and activities of the learning environment
Premises.P7: Exam task should be varied to give fair opportunities to candidates with different types of skills
Premises.P8: Other types of assessment should also be considered, assignment writing, for example, to assess independent learning and research skills, or group projects, to measure teamwork ability
